column2: CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO
column3: CHAPTER TWENTY TWO

column2: PLEASANT MEADOWS
column3: PLEASANT MEADOWS

column2: Like sunshine after a storm were the peaceful weeks which followed. The invalids improved rapidly, and Mr. March began to talk of returning early in the new year.
column3: Like sunshine after a storm were the peaceful weeks which followed. The invalids improved rapidly, and mr March began to talk of returning early in the new year.

column2: Beth was soon able to lie on the study sofa all day, amusing herself with the well-beloved cats at first, and in time with doll's sewing, which had fallen sadly behind-hand.
column3: Beth was soon able to lie on the study sofa all day, amusing herself with the well beloved cats at first, and in time with doll's sewing, which had fallen sadly behind hand.

column2: Her once active limbs were so stiff and feeble that Jo took her for a daily airing about the house in her strong arms.
column3: Her once active limbs were so stiff and feeble that Jo took her for a daily airing about the house in her strong arms.

column2: Meg cheerfully blackened and burned her white hands cooking delicate messes for 'the dear', while Amy, a loyal slave of the ring, celebrated her return by giving away as many of her treasures as she could prevail on her sisters to accept.
column3: Meg cheerfully blackened and burned her white hands cooking delicate messes for 'the dear', while Amy, a loyal slave of the ring, celebrated her return by giving away as many of her treasures as she could prevail on her sisters to accept.

column2: As Christmas approached, the usual mysteries began to haunt the house, and Jo frequently convulsed the family by proposing utterly impossible or magnificently absurd ceremonies, in honor of this unusually merry Christmas.
column3: As Christmas approached, the usual mysteries began to haunt the house, and Jo frequently convulsed the family by proposing utterly impossible or magnificently absurd ceremonies, in honor of this unusually merry Christmas.

column2: Laurie was equally impracticable, and would have had bonfires, skyrockets, and triumphal arches, if he had had his own way. After many skirmishes and snubbings, the ambitious pair were considered effectually quenched and went about with forlorn faces, which were rather belied by explosions of laughter when the two got together.
column3: Laurie was equally impracticable, and would have had bonfires, skyrockets, and triumphal arches, if he had had his own way. After many skirmishes and snubbings, the ambitious pair were considered effectually quenched and went about with forlorn faces, which were rather belied by explosions of laughter when the two got together.

column2: Several days of unusually mild weather fitly ushered in a splendid Christmas Day.
column3: Several days of unusually mild weather fitly ushered in a splendid Christmas Day.

column2: Hannah 'felt in her bones' that it was going to be an unusually fine day, and she proved herself a true prophetess, for everybody and everything seemed bound to produce a grand success.
column3: Hannah 'felt in her bones' that it was going to be an unusually fine day, and she proved herself a true prophetess, for everybody and everything seemed bound to produce a grand success.

column2: To begin with, Mr. March wrote that he should soon be with them, then Beth felt uncommonly well that morning, and, being dressed in her mother's gift, a soft crimson merino wrapper, was borne in high triumph to the window to behold the offering of Jo and Laurie.
column3: To begin with, mr March wrote that he should soon be with them, then Beth felt uncommonly well that morning, and, being dressed in her mother's gift, a soft crimson merino wrapper, was borne in high triumph to the window to behold the offering of Jo and Laurie.

column2: The Unquenchables had done their best to be worthy of the name, for like elves they had worked by night and conjured up a comical surprise.
column3: The Unquenchables had done their best to be worthy of the name, for like elves they had worked by night and conjured up a comical surprise.

column2: Out in the garden stood a stately snow maiden, crowned with holly, bearing a basket of fruit and flowers in one hand, a great roll of music in the other, a perfect rainbow of an Afghan round her chilly shoulders, and a Christmas carol issuing from her lips on a pink paper streamer.
column3: Out in the garden stood a stately snow maiden, crowned with holly, bearing a basket of fruit and flowers in one hand, a great roll of music in the other, a perfect rainbow of an Afghan round her chilly shoulders, and a Christmas carol issuing from her lips on a pink paper streamer.

column2: THE JUNGFRAU TO BETH
column3: THE JUNGFRAU TO BETH

column2: God bless you, dear Queen Bess! May nothing you dismay, But health and peace and happiness Be yours, this Christmas day.
column3: God bless you, dear Queen Bess! May nothing you dismay, But health and peace and happiness Be yours, this Christmas day.

column2: Here's fruit to feed our busy bee, And flowers for her nose. Here's music for her pianee, An afghan for her toes,
column3: Here's fruit to feed our busy bee, And flowers for her nose. Here's music for her pianee, An afghan for her toes,

column2: A portrait of Joanna, see, By Raphael No. 2, Who laboured with great industry To make it fair and true.
column3: A portrait of Joanna, see, By Raphael no two, Who laboured with great industry To make it fair and true.

column2: Accept a ribbon red, I beg, For Madam Purrer's tail, And ice cream made by lovely Peg, A Mont Blanc in a pail.
column3: Accept a ribbon red, I beg, For Madam Purrer's tail, And ice cream made by lovely Peg, A Mont Blanc in a pail.

column2: Their dearest love my makers laid Within my breast of snow. Accept it, and the Alpine maid, From Laurie and from Jo.
column3: Their dearest love my makers laid Within my breast of snow. Accept it, and the Alpine maid, From Laurie and from Jo.

column2: How Beth laughed when she saw it, how Laurie ran up and down to bring in the gifts, and what ridiculous speeches Jo made as she presented them.
column3: How Beth laughed when she saw it, how Laurie ran up and down to bring in the gifts, and what ridiculous speeches Jo made as she presented them.

column2: I'm so full of happiness, that if Father was only here, I couldn't hold one drop more, said Beth, quite sighing with contentment as Jo carried her off to the study to rest after the excitement, and to refresh herself with some of the delicious grapes the 'Jungfrau' had sent her.
column3: I'm so full of happiness, that if Father was only here, I couldn't hold one drop more, said Beth, quite sighing with contentment as Jo carried her off to the study to rest after the excitement, and to refresh herself with some of the delicious grapes the 'Jungfrau' had sent her.

column2: So am I, added Jo, slapping the pocket wherein reposed the long-desired _Undine and Sintram_.
column3: So am I, added Jo, slapping the pocket wherein reposed the long desired underscore Undine and Sintram underscore.

column2: I'm sure I am, echoed Amy, poring over the engraved copy of the Madonna and Child, which her mother had given her in a pretty frame.
column3: I'm sure I am, echoed Amy, poring over the engraved copy of the Madonna and Child, which her mother had given her in a pretty frame.

column2: Of course I am! cried Meg, smoothing the silvery folds of her first silk dress, for Mr. Laurence had insisted on giving it.
column3: Of course I am! cried Meg, smoothing the silvery folds of her first silk dress, for mr Laurence had insisted on giving it.

column2: How can I be otherwise? said Mrs. March gratefully, as her eyes went from her husband's letter to Beth's smiling face, and her hand carressed the brooch made of gray and golden, chestnut and dark brown hair, which the girls had just fastened on her breast.
column3: How can I be otherwise? said mrs March gratefully, as her eyes went from her husband's letter to Beth's smiling face, and her hand carressed the brooch made of gray and golden, chestnut and dark brown hair, which the girls had just fastened on her breast.

column2: Now and then, in this workaday world, things do happen in the delightful storybook fashion, and what a comfort it is.
column3: Now and then, in this workaday world, things do happen in the delightful storybook fashion, and what a comfort it is.

column2: Half an hour after everyone had said they were so happy they could only hold one drop more, the drop came.
column3: Half an hour after everyone had said they were so happy they could only hold one drop more, the drop came.

column2: Laurie opened the parlor door and popped his head in very quietly.
column3: Laurie opened the parlor door and popped his head in very quietly.

column2: He might just as well have turned a somersault and uttered an Indian war whoop, for his face was so full of suppressed excitement and his voice so treacherously joyful that everyone jumped up, though he only said, in a queer, breathless voice, "Here's another Christmas present for the March family."
column3: He might just as well have turned a somersault and uttered an Indian war whoop, for his face was so full of suppressed excitement and his voice so treacherously joyful that everyone jumped up, though he only said, in a queer, breathless voice, "Here's another Christmas present for the March family."

column2: Before the words were well out of his mouth, he was whisked away somehow, and in his place appeared a tall man, muffled up to the eyes, leaning on the arm of another tall man, who tried to say something and couldn't.
column3: Before the words were well out of his mouth, he was whisked away somehow, and in his place appeared a tall man, muffled up to the eyes, leaning on the arm of another tall man, who tried to say something and couldn't.

column2: Of course there was a general stampede, and for several minutes everybody seemed to lose their wits, for the strangest things were done, and no one said a word.
column3: Of course there was a general stampede, and for several minutes everybody seemed to lose their wits, for the strangest things were done, and no one said a word.

column2: Mr. March became invisible in the embrace of four pairs of loving arms. Jo disgraced herself by nearly fainting away, and had to be doctored by Laurie in the china closet.
column3: mr March became invisible in the embrace of four pairs of loving arms. Jo disgraced herself by nearly fainting away, and had to be doctored by Laurie in the china closet.

column2: Mr. Brooke kissed Meg entirely by mistake, as he somewhat incoherently explained.
column3: mr Brooke kissed Meg entirely by mistake, as he somewhat incoherently explained.

column2: And Amy, the dignified, tumbled over a stool, and never stopping to get up, hugged and cried over her father's boots in the most touching manner.
column3: And Amy, the dignified, tumbled over a stool, and never stopping to get up, hugged and cried over her father's boots in the most touching manner.

column2: Mrs. March was the first to recover herself, and held up her hand with a warning, "Hush! Remember Beth."
column3: mrs March was the first to recover herself, and held up her hand with a warning, "Hush! Remember Beth."

column2: But it was too late.
column3: But it was too late.

column2: The study door flew open, the little red wrapper appeared on the threshold, joy put strength into the feeble limbs, and Beth ran straight into her father's arms.
column3: The study door flew open, the little red wrapper appeared on the threshold, joy put strength into the feeble limbs, and Beth ran straight into her father's arms.

column2: Never mind what happened just after that, for the full hearts overflowed, washing away the bitterness of the past and leaving only the sweetness of the present.
column3: Never mind what happened just after that, for the full hearts overflowed, washing away the bitterness of the past and leaving only the sweetness of the present.

column2: It was not at all romantic, but a hearty laugh set everybody straight again, for Hannah was discovered behind the door, sobbing over the fat turkey, which she had forgotten to put down when she rushed up from the kitchen.
column3: It was not at all romantic, but a hearty laugh set everybody straight again, for Hannah was discovered behind the door, sobbing over the fat turkey, which she had forgotten to put down when she rushed up from the kitchen.

column2: As the laugh subsided, Mrs. March began to thank Mr. Brooke for his faithful care of her husband, at which Mr. Brooke suddenly remembered that Mr. March needed rest, and seizing Laurie, he precipitately retired.
column3: As the laugh subsided, mrs March began to thank mr Brooke for his faithful care of her husband, at which mr Brooke suddenly remembered that mr March needed rest, and seizing Laurie, he precipitately retired.

column2: Then the two invalids were ordered to repose, which they did, by both sitting in one big chair and talking hard.
column3: Then the two invalids were ordered to repose, which they did, by both sitting in one big chair and talking hard.

column2: Mr. March told how he had longed to surprise them, and how, when the fine weather came, he had been allowed by his doctor to take advantage of it, how devoted Brooke had been, and how he was altogether a most estimable and upright young man.
column3: mr March told how he had longed to surprise them, and how, when the fine weather came, he had been allowed by his doctor to take advantage of it, how devoted Brooke had been, and how he was altogether a most estimable and upright young man.

column2: Why Mr. March paused a minute just there, and after a glance at Meg, who was violently poking the fire, looked at his wife with an inquiring lift of the eyebrows, I leave you to imagine.
column3: Why mr March paused a minute just there, and after a glance at Meg, who was violently poking the fire, looked at his wife with an inquiring lift of the eyebrows, I leave you to imagine.

column2: Also why Mrs. March gently nodded her head and asked, rather abruptly, if he wouldn't like to have something to eat.
column3: Also why mrs March gently nodded her head and asked, rather abruptly, if he wouldn't like to have something to eat.

column2: Jo saw and understood the look, and she stalked grimly away to get wine and beef tea, muttering to herself as she slammed the door, "I hate estimable young men with brown eyes!"
column3: Jo saw and understood the look, and she stalked grimly away to get wine and beef tea, muttering to herself as she slammed the door, "I hate estimable young men with brown eyes!"

column2: There never was such a Christmas dinner as they had that day.
column3: There never was such a Christmas dinner as they had that day.

column2: The fat turkey was a sight to behold, when Hannah sent him up, stuffed, browned, and decorated.
column3: The fat turkey was a sight to behold, when Hannah sent him up, stuffed, browned, and decorated.

column2: So was the plum pudding, which melted in one's mouth, likewise the jellies, in which Amy reveled like a fly in a honeypot.
column3: So was the plum pudding, which melted in one's mouth, likewise the jellies, in which Amy reveled like a fly in a honeypot.

column2: Everything turned out well, which was a mercy, Hannah said, "For my mind was that flustered, Mum, that it's a merrycle I didn't roast the pudding, and stuff the turkey with raisins, let alone bilin' of it in a cloth."
column3: Everything turned out well, which was a mercy, Hannah said, "For my mind was that flustered, Mum, that it's a merrycle I didn't roast the pudding, and stuff the turkey with raisins, let alone bilin' of it in a cloth."

column2: Mr. Laurence and his grandson dined with them, also Mr. Brooke, at whom Jo glowered darkly, to Laurie's infinite amusement.
column3: mr Laurence and his grandson dined with them, also mr Brooke, at whom Jo glowered darkly, to Laurie's infinite amusement.

column2: Two easy chairs stood side by side at the head of the table, in which sat Beth and her father, feasting modestly on chicken and a little fruit.
column3: Two easy chairs stood side by side at the head of the table, in which sat Beth and her father, feasting modestly on chicken and a little fruit.

column2: They drank healths, told stories, sang songs, 'reminisced', as the old folks say, and had a thoroughly good time.
column3: They drank healths, told stories, sang songs, 'reminisced', as the old folks say, and had a thoroughly good time.

column2: A sleigh ride had been planned, but the girls would not leave their father, so the guests departed early, and as twilight gathered, the happy family sat together round the fire.
column3: A sleigh ride had been planned, but the girls would not leave their father, so the guests departed early, and as twilight gathered, the happy family sat together round the fire.

column2: Just a year ago we were groaning over the dismal Christmas we expected to have.	Just a year ago we were groaning over the dismal Christmas we expected to have.
column3: true

column2: Do you remember?" asked Jo, breaking a short pause which had followed a long conversation about many things.
column3: Do you remember?" asked Jo, breaking a short pause which had followed a long conversation about many things.

column2: Rather a pleasant year on the whole! said Meg, smiling at the fire, and congratulating herself on having treated Mr. Brooke with dignity.
column3: Rather a pleasant year on the whole! said Meg, smiling at the fire, and congratulating herself on having treated mr Brooke with dignity.

column2: I think it's been a pretty hard one, observed Amy, watching the light shine on her ring with thoughtful eyes.
column3: I think it's been a pretty hard one, observed Amy, watching the light shine on her ring with thoughtful eyes.

column2: I'm glad it's over, because we've got you back, whispered Beth, who sat on her father's knee.
column3: I'm glad it's over, because we've got you back, whispered Beth, who sat on her father's knee.

column2: Rather a rough road for you to travel, my little pilgrims, especially the latter part of it.	Rather a rough road for you to travel, my little pilgrims, especially the latter part of it.
column3: true

column2: But you have got on bravely, and I think the burdens are in a fair way to tumble off very soon," said Mr. March, looking with fatherly satisfaction at the four young faces gathered round him.
column3: But you have got on bravely, and I think the burdens are in a fair way to tumble off very soon," said mr March, looking with fatherly satisfaction at the four young faces gathered round him.

column2: How do you know?	How do you know?
column3: true

column2: Did Mother tell you?" asked Jo.
column3: Did Mother tell you?" asked Jo.

column2: Not much.	Not much.
column3: true

column2: Straws show which way the wind blows, and I've made several discoveries today."
column3: Straws show which way the wind blows, and I've made several discoveries today."

column2: Oh, tell us what they are! cried Meg, who sat beside him.
column3: Oh, tell us what they are! cried Meg, who sat beside him.

column2: Here is one. And taking up the hand which lay on the arm of his chair, he pointed to the roughened forefinger, a burn on the back, and two or three little hard spots on the palm.
column3: Here is one. And taking up the hand which lay on the arm of his chair, he pointed to the roughened forefinger, a burn on the back, and two or three little hard spots on the palm.

column2: I remember a time when this hand was white and smooth, and your first care was to keep it so. It was very pretty then, but to me it is much prettier now, for in this seeming blemishes I read a little history.	I remember a time when this hand was white and smooth, and your first care was to keep it so. It was very pretty then, but to me it is much prettier now, for in this seeming blemishes I read a little history.
column3: false

column2: A burnt offering has been made to vanity, this hardened palm has earned something better than blisters, and I'm sure the sewing done by these pricked fingers will last a long time, so much good will went into the stitches.
column3: A burnt offering has been made to vanity, this hardened palm has earned something better than blisters, and I'm sure the sewing done by these pricked fingers will last a long time, so much good will went into the stitches.

column2: Meg, my dear, I value the womanly skill which keeps home happy more than white hands or fashionable accomplishments.
column3: Meg, my dear, I value the womanly skill which keeps home happy more than white hands or fashionable accomplishments.

column2: I'm proud to shake this good, industrious little hand, and hope I shall not soon be asked to give it away."
column3: I'm proud to shake this good, industrious little hand, and hope I shall not soon be asked to give it away."

column2: If Meg had wanted a reward for hours of patient labor, she received it in the hearty pressure of her father's hand and the approving smile he gave her.
column3: If Meg had wanted a reward for hours of patient labor, she received it in the hearty pressure of her father's hand and the approving smile he gave her.

column2: What about Jo?	What about Jo?
column3: true

column2: Please say something nice, for she has tried so hard and been so very, very good to me," said Beth in her father's ear.
column3: Please say something nice, for she has tried so hard and been so very, very good to me," said Beth in her father's ear.

column2: He laughed and looked across at the tall girl who sat opposite, with an unusually mild expression in her face.
column3: He laughed and looked across at the tall girl who sat opposite, with an unusually mild expression in her face.

column2: In spite of the curly crop, I don't see the 'son Jo' whom I left a year ago, said Mr. March.
column3: In spite of the curly crop, I don't see the 'son Jo' whom I left a year ago, said mr March.

column2: I see a young lady who pins her collar straight, laces her boots neatly, and neither whistles, talks slang, nor lies on the rug as she used to do.	I see a young lady who pins her collar straight, laces her boots neatly, and neither whistles, talks slang, nor lies on the rug as she used to do.
column3: true

column2: Her face is rather thin and pale just now, with watching and anxiety, but I like to look at it, for it has grown gentler, and her voice is lower.
column3: Her face is rather thin and pale just now, with watching and anxiety, but I like to look at it, for it has grown gentler, and her voice is lower.

column2: She doesn't bounce, but moves quietly, and takes care of a certain little person in a motherly way which delights me.
column3: She doesn't bounce, but moves quietly, and takes care of a certain little person in a motherly way which delights me.

column2: I rather miss my wild girl, but if I get a strong, helpful, tenderhearted woman in her place, I shall feel quite satisfied.
column3: I rather miss my wild girl, but if I get a strong, helpful, tenderhearted woman in her place, I shall feel quite satisfied.

column2: I don't know whether the shearing sobered our black sheep, but I do know that in all Washington I couldn't find anything beautiful enough to be bought with the five-and-twenty dollars my good girl sent me."
column3: I don't know whether the shearing sobered our black sheep, but I do know that in all Washington I couldn't find anything beautiful enough to be bought with the five and twenty dollars my good girl sent me."

column2: Jo's keen eyes were rather dim for a minute, and her thin face grew rosy in the firelight as she received her father's praise, feeling that she did deserve a portion of it.
column3: Jo's keen eyes were rather dim for a minute, and her thin face grew rosy in the firelight as she received her father's praise, feeling that she did deserve a portion of it.

column2: Now, Beth, said Amy, longing for her turn, but ready to wait.
column3: Now, Beth, said Amy, longing for her turn, but ready to wait.

column2: There's so little of her, I'm afraid to say much, for fear she will slip away altogether, though she is not so shy as she used to be, began their father cheerfully.
column3: There's so little of her, I'm afraid to say much, for fear she will slip away altogether, though she is not so shy as she used to be, began their father cheerfully.

column2: But recollecting how nearly he had lost her, he held her close, saying tenderly, with her cheek against his own, "I've got you safe, my Beth, and I'll keep you so, please God."
column3: But recollecting how nearly he had lost her, he held her close, saying tenderly, with her cheek against his own, "I've got you safe, my Beth, and I'll keep you so, please God."

column2: After a minute's silence, he looked down at Amy, who sat on the cricket at his feet, and said, with a caress of the shining hair...
column3: After a minute's silence, he looked down at Amy, who sat on the cricket at his feet, and said, with a caress of the shining hair...

column2: I observed that Amy took drumsticks at dinner, ran errands for her mother all the afternoon, gave Meg her place tonight, and has waited on every one with patience and good humor.	I observed that Amy took drumsticks at dinner, ran errands for her mother all the afternoon, gave Meg her place tonight, and has waited on every one with patience and good humor.
column3: true

column2: I also observe that she does not fret much nor look in the glass, and has not even mentioned a very pretty ring which she wears, so I conclude that she has learned to think of other people more and of herself less, and has decided to try and mold her character as carefully as she molds her little clay figures.
column3: I also observe that she does not fret much nor look in the glass, and has not even mentioned a very pretty ring which she wears, so I conclude that she has learned to think of other people more and of herself less, and has decided to try and mold her character as carefully as she molds her little clay figures.

column2: I am glad of this, for though I should be very proud of a graceful statue made by her, I shall be infinitely prouder of a lovable daughter with a talent for making life beautiful to herself and others."
column3: I am glad of this, for though I should be very proud of a graceful statue made by her, I shall be infinitely prouder of a lovable daughter with a talent for making life beautiful to herself and others."

column2: What are you thinking of, Beth? asked Jo, when Amy had thanked her father and told about her ring.
column3: What are you thinking of, Beth? asked Jo, when Amy had thanked her father and told about her ring.

column2: I read in _Pilgrim's Progress_ today how, after many troubles, Christian and Hopeful came to a pleasant green meadow where lilies bloomed all year round, and there they rested happily, as we do now, before they went on to their journey's end, answered Beth, adding, as she slipped out of her father's arms and went to the instrument, "It's singing time now, and I want to be in my old place.
column3: I read in underscore Pilgrim's Progress underscore today how, after many troubles, Christian and Hopeful came to a pleasant green meadow where lilies bloomed all year round, and there they rested happily, as we do now, before they went on to their journey's end, answered Beth, adding, as she slipped out of her father's arms and went to the instrument, "It's singing time now, and I want to be in my old place.

column2: I'll try to sing the song of the shepherd boy which the Pilgrims heard.
column3: I'll try to sing the song of the shepherd boy which the Pilgrims heard.

column2: I made the music for Father, because he likes the verses."
column3: I made the music for Father, because he likes the verses."

column2: So, sitting at the dear little piano, Beth softly touched the keys, and in the sweet voice they had never thought to hear again, sang to her own accompaniment the quaint hymn, which was a singularly fitting song for her.
column3: So, sitting at the dear little piano, Beth softly touched the keys, and in the sweet voice they had never thought to hear again, sang to her own accompaniment the quaint hymn, which was a singularly fitting song for her.

column2: He that is down need fear no fall, He that is low no pride. He that is humble ever shall Have God to be his guide.
column3: He that is down need fear no fall, He that is low no pride. He that is humble ever shall Have God to be his guide.

column2: I am content with what I have, Little be it, or much. And, Lord!
column3: I am content with what I have, Little be it, or much. And, Lord!

column2: Contentment still I crave, Because Thou savest such.
column3: Contentment still I crave, Because Thou savest such.

column2: Fulness to them a burden is, That go on pilgrimage. Here little, and hereafter bliss, Is best from age to age!
column3: Fulness to them a burden is, That go on pilgrimage. Here little, and hereafter bliss, Is best from age to age!

column2: CHAPTER TWENTY-THREE
column3: CHAPTER TWENTY THREE

column2: AUNT MARCH SETTLES THE QUESTION
column3: AUNT MARCH SETTLES THE QUESTION

column2: Like bees swarming after their queen, mother and daughters hovered about Mr. March the next day, neglecting everything to look at, wait upon, and listen to the new invalid, who was in a fair way to be killed by kindness.
column3: Like bees swarming after their queen, mother and daughters hovered about mr March the next day, neglecting everything to look at, wait upon, and listen to the new invalid, who was in a fair way to be killed by kindness.

column2: As he sat propped up in a big chair by Beth's sofa, with the other three close by, and Hannah popping in her head now and then 'to peek at the dear man', nothing seemed needed to complete their happiness.
column3: As he sat propped up in a big chair by Beth's sofa, with the other three close by, and Hannah popping in her head now and then 'to peek at the dear man', nothing seemed needed to complete their happiness.

column2: But something was needed, and the elder ones felt it, though none confessed the fact.
column3: But something was needed, and the elder ones felt it, though none confessed the fact.

column2: Mr. and Mrs. March looked at one another with an anxious expression, as their eyes followed Meg.
column3: mr and mrs March looked at one another with an anxious expression, as their eyes followed Meg.

column2: Jo had sudden fits of sobriety, and was seen to shake her fist at Mr. Brooke's umbrella, which had been left in the hall.
column3: Jo had sudden fits of sobriety, and was seen to shake her fist at mr Brooke's umbrella, which had been left in the hall.

column2: Meg was absent-minded, shy, and silent, started when the bell rang, and colored when John's name was mentioned.
column3: Meg was absent minded, shy, and silent, started when the bell rang, and colored when John's name was mentioned.

column2: Amy said, "Everyone seemed waiting for something, and couldn't settle down, which was queer, since Father was safe at home," and Beth innocently wondered why their neighbors didn't run over as usual.
column3: Amy said, "Everyone seemed waiting for something, and couldn't settle down, which was queer, since Father was safe at home," and Beth innocently wondered why their neighbors didn't run over as usual.
